quizzes.question: What does SVG stand for?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Drawing Shapes [/h1]

[b]SVG [/b]stands for [b]S[/b]calable [b]V[/b]ector [b]G[/b]raphics, and is used to draw shapes with HTML-style markup.

It offers several methods for drawing paths, boxes, circles, text, and graphic images. 

[note]SVG is not pixel-based, so it can be magnified infinitely with no loss of quality.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to create a red circle at the position X=50, Y=240:
[!raw!]
<svg width="1000" height="1000">
   <{0} cx="50" {1}="240" 
    r="10" {2}="red" />
</{3}>
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Drawing a Circle[/h1]

To draw shapes with SVG, you first need to create an [b]SVG [/b]element tag with two attributes: width and height. [code format="html" ]<[b]svg width[/b]="1000" [b]height[/b]="1000">[b]</svg>[/b][/code]
To create a circle, add a [b]<circle>[/b] tag: [code format="html" codeId="49"]<svg width="2000" height="2000">
   <circle cx="80" cy="80" r="50" fill="green" />
</svg>[/code]
 - [b]cx [/b]pushes the center of the circle further to the right of the screen
 - [b]cy [/b]pushes the center of the circle further down from the top of the screen
 - [b]r[/b] defines the radius
 - [b]fill [/b]determines the color of our circle
 - [b]stroke [/b]adds an outline to the circle

[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2549" width="100%"]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to add a line to the page, starting from coordinates 10, 20 and ending at 50, 100:
[!raw!]
<svg width="500" height="500">
   <{0} x1="10" {1}="20"
    {2}="50" y2="100" />
</svg>
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Other Shape Elements [/h1]

[b]<rect>[/b]  defines a rectangle: [code format="html" codeId="50"]<svg width="2000" height="2000">
   <[b]rect[/b] width="300" height="100" 
     x="20" y="20" fill="green" />
</svg>[/code]
The following code will draw a green-filled rectangle. [img id="2550" width="100%"]
[b]<line>[/b] defines a line segment: [code format="html" codeId="51"]<svg width="400" height="410">
    <line x1="10" y1="10" x2="200" y2="100" 
        style="stroke:#000000; stroke-linecap:round; 
        stroke-width:20"  />
</svg>[/code]
(x1, y1) define the start coordinates(x2, y2) define the end coordinates. [img id="2551" width="100%"]
[b]<polyline>[/b] defines shapes built from multiple line definitions: [code format="html" codeId="52"]<svg width="2000" height="500">
    <polyline style="stroke-linejoin:miter; stroke:black; 
        stroke-width:12; fill: none;"
        points="100 100, 150 150, 200 100" />
</svg>[/code]
Points are the polyline's coordinates.

quizzes.question: Which of the following is an HTML5 SVG shape?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]<ellipse> and <polygon>[/h1]

[u][b]Ellipse[/b][/u]
The <[b]ellipse[/b]> is similar to the <[b]circle[/b]>, with one exception: 
You can independently change the horizontal and vertical axes of its radius, using the [b]rx [/b]and [b]ry [/b]attributes. [code format="html" codeId="53"]<svg height="500" width="1000">
   <ellipse cx="200" cy="100" rx="150" ry="70" style="fill:green" />
</svg>[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2553" width="100%"]

[u][b]Polygon [/b][/u]
The [b]<polygon> [/b]element is used to create a graphic with at least three sides. The polygon element is unique because it automatically closes off the shape for you. [code format="html" codeId="54"]<svg width="2000" height="2000">
<polygon points="100 100, 200 200, 300 0" 
      style="fill: green; stroke:black;" />
</svg>[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2554" width="100%"]
